Award.AwardTitle: Algorithms for Measurement Model Specification Search
Award.AbstractNarration:
When scientists in many fields such as educational research, psychometrics, sociology, economics, etc. are interested in knowing the values of, or inferring causal relations between variables that they cannot directly measure, they typically record several survey or test "items" that are thought to be indicators of latent variables of interest, e.g. "mathematical ability" (educational research) or personality traits such as "impulsiveness" (psychometrics). Although it is rare that a latent variable is measured perfectly by any single indicator, estimates of the latent variables, and their associations with other latents, can be obtained by employing multiple indicators for each latent variable. If the multiple indicator model is correctly specified, then in a wide range of cases the estimates obtained are consistent and have desirable statistical properties, and these estimates can be used to search for causal models among the latents. If the model is mis-specified, then estimators are typically biased, and search for causal models among the latents is more difficult. A number of problems make it difficult to find a correctly specified measurement model from background knowledge and samples of the measured variables: a) associations among items are often confounded by additional unknown latent common causes, b) there are often a plethora of alternative models that are consistent with the data and with the prior knowledge of domain experts, c) there may be non-linear dependencies among latent variables, or linear relationships among non-Gaussian latent variables, and d) there may be feedback relationships among latent variables. The investigator and his colleagues perform research that utilizes and generalizes recent work in algebraic statistics on rank constraints on sub-matrices of the measured correlation matrix that are robustly entailed by given measurement models, in order to construct reliable search algorithms that allow scientists to find correctly specified measurement models using background knowledge and sample data, and to use the measurement models to reliably construct models that specify how the latent variables are causally related to each other.

Since the early 20th century, beginning with the work of Charles Spearman on finding statistical evidence for a single trait he called "general intelligence," there has been controversy on how to scientifically determine the dimensions of personality and mental abilities; e.g. is there one dimension to intelligence ("general intelligence") or are there many different kinds of intelligence? Although there has been a great deal of progress in psychometrics, psychometric methods are still rapidly evolving. The investigators and their colleagues study how to use evidence from survey data to reliably conclude how many dimensions various personality and mental abilities have, and to construct psychological theories based on these conclusions. Potential applications include building effective educational interventions, building effective surveys for detecting personality disorders, and building effective surveys for measuring mental health in individuals and in populations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project has been devoted to helping psychometric researchers systematically search a very large space of alternative models using just the background assumptions that are well justified, in order to improve psychometric models.

Psychometrics studies causal relationships between latent “factor” variables that cannot be directly measured (e.g. mathematics ability and socio-economic status). Instead, they are measured indirectly through “indicator” variables that can be directly measured and are informative about the values of factors that cannot be directly measured. The inference from measurements of indicator variables to causal relations between factors, typically is done in two steps: first form a causal model of the relationship between the factors and the indicators (the “measurement model”), and second, form a causal model of the relationships between the latent factors (the “structural model”.) In practice, both of these models are usually formed from background assumptions about the domain of interest, and the sample data from the indicators is used to test the hypothesized models. Sometimes some modifications of a hypothesized model is made if the hypothesized models fail to pass a statistical test using the sample values of the indicator variables.

This method has several major problems. First, it is often the case that there is not enough real knowledge about the domain to form the structural and measurement models, so the assumptions made are often not well justified. For example, the measurement model often assumes that answers to questions (e.g. questions about mathematics problems) are caused by some latent factor of interest (e.g. mathematics ability); such assumptions based on domain knowledge is plausible in many cases. However, it is also often assumed that the latent factor of interest (e.g. mathematics ability) is the only common cause of answers to questions about mathematics problems (ignoring, e.g. reading ability in order to understand the question). Again, it is also often assumed and whether there are not several different types of mathematics ability (e.g. algebraic, geometric, etc.). These latter kinds of assumptions are often much less plausibly known through domain knowledge. In general, searching for models in this way produces causal models that do not pass statistical tests – this has led researchers to suggest a variety of measures of the goodness of a causal model, but it has not been show that any these alternative measures are reliable. 

We aid researchers in finding measurement models that perform much better on statistical tests. The search space of measurement models is immense, and beyond the capabilities of any human to search thoroughly. We have two strategies for searching the space of alternative measurement models in feasible amounts of time, that we have employed in the algorithms that we have devised (Find One Factor Clusters, Find Two Factor Clusters, and combinations of these). First, instead of searching for a measurement model over all of the indicators, we limit the search space by looking only for simple models on subsets of the indicators. In particular, we search for “pure” measurement models, in which there are no pairs of indicators in which one causes the other, or which have correlated errors. Second, the automated searches that we have devised for measurement models perform the search by looking for measurement models that as closely as possible entail constraints on the rank of sub-matrices of the covariance matrix among the indicators judged to hold in the population based on the outcomes of statistical tests. These tests can be performed quite quickly and generally do not require iterative algorithms. 

We have also recently expanded the search space for measurement models, so that it is not necessary to assume that all of the indicators are effects of the latent factors, and that the entire sample comes from the same measurement model. Instead, we include the possibility that some of the indicators are causes, rather than effects, of the latent factors, and in which the sample may come from several different measurement models that agree on the existence of the causal relations between the latent factors and the indicators, but disagree on the size of the cause relations.

We have also devised a search algorithm (t-separation based MIMBUILD) for structural models. Unlike previous structural model search algorithms, the algorithm that we have devised allows for the possibility that the indicators are caused by multiple factors, rather than a single factor.

Together, these algorithms allow researchers to use only background assumptions that they are confident are true, to relax some of the assumptions that are commonly made about measurement and structural models, and to quickly search for good models in a vastly expanded space of alternatives. The algorithms that we developed are available for free in the TETRAD program.
